channel.title: Quanta Science Podcast
channel.description: In-depth news about mathematics, physics, biology and computer science. Read more at QuantaMagazine.org.
channel.itunes:summary: Listen to Quanta Magazine's in-depth news stories about developments in mathematics, theoretical physics, theoretical computer science and the basic life sciences. Quanta, an editorially independent magazine published by the Simons Foundation, seeks to enhance public understanding of basic research. Read more at QuantaMagazine.org.
channel.itunes:author: Quanta Magazine
channel.itunes:subtitle: In-depth news about mathematics, physics, biology and computer science.

item.title: Mathematicians Outwit Hidden Number Conspiracy
item.description:
Decades ago, a mathematician posed a warmup problem for some of the most difficult questions about prime numbers. It turned out to be just as difficult to solve, until now.

The post Mathematicians Outwit Hidden Number Conspiracy first appeared on Quanta Magazine
item.itunes:title: Mathematicians Outwit Hidden Number Conspiracy
item.itunes:subtitle: Decades ago, a mathematician posed a warmup problem for some of the most difficult questions about prime numbers. It turned out to be just as difficult to solve, until now.
item.itunes:summary: Decades ago, a mathematician posed a warmup problem for some of the most difficult questions about prime numbers. It turned out to be just as difficult to solve, until now. Read more at QuantaMagazine.org. Music is "Aimless Amos" by Rondo Brothers.
item.itunes:author: Quanta Magazine
item.content:encoded:
Decades ago, a mathematician posed a warmup problem for some of the most difficult questions about prime numbers. It turned out to be just as difficult to solve, until now.

The post Mathematicians Outwit Hidden Number Conspiracy first appeared on Quanta Magazine

item.title: Mathematician Hurls Structure and Disorder Into Century-Old Problem
item.description:
A new paper shows how to create longer disordered strings than mathematicians had thought possible, proving that a well-known recent conjecture is “spectacularly wrong.”

The post Mathematician Hurls Structure and Disorder Into Century-Old Problem first appeared on Quanta Magazine
item.itunes:title: Mathematician Hurls Structure and Disorder Into Century-Old Problem
item.itunes:subtitle: A new paper shows how to create longer disordered strings than mathematicians had thought possible, proving that a well-known recent conjecture is "spectacularly wrong."
item.itunes:summary: A new paper shows how to create longer disordered strings than mathematicians had thought possible, proving that a well-known recent conjecture is "spectacularly wrong." Read more at QuantaMagazine.org. Music is "Transmission" by John Deley and the 41 Players.
item.itunes:author: Quanta Magazine
item.content:encoded:
A new paper shows how to create longer disordered strings than mathematicians had thought possible, proving that a well-known recent conjecture is “spectacularly wrong.”

The post Mathematician Hurls Structure and Disorder Into Century-Old Problem first appeared on Quanta Magazine

item.title: Researchers Defeat Randomness to Create Ideal Code
item.description:
By carefully constructing a multidimensional and well-connected graph, a team of researchers has finally created a long-sought locally testable code that can immediately betray whether it’s been corrupted.

The post Researchers Defeat Randomness to Create Ideal Code first appeared on Quanta Magazine
item.itunes:title: Researchers Defeat Randomness to Create Ideal Code
item.itunes:subtitle: By carefully constructing a multidimensional and well-connected graph, a team of researchers has finally created a long-sought locally testable code that can immediately betray whether it's been corrupted.
item.itunes:summary: By carefully constructing a multidimensional and well-connected graph, a team of researchers has finally created a long-sought locally testable code that can immediately reveal whether it's been corrupted. Read more at QuantaMagazine.org. Music is "Clover 3" by Vibe Mountain.
item.itunes:author: Quanta Magazine
item.content:encoded:
By carefully constructing a multidimensional and well-connected graph, a team of researchers has finally created a long-sought locally testable code that can immediately betray whether it’s been corrupted.

item.title: The Brain Processes Speech in Parallel With Other Sounds
item.description:
Scientists thought that the brain’s hearing centers might just process speech along with other sounds. But new work suggests that speech gets some special treatment very early on.

The post The Brain Processes Speech in Parallel With Other Sounds first appeared on Quanta Magazine
item.itunes:title: The Brain Processes Speech in Parallel With Other Sounds
item.itunes:subtitle: Scientists thought that the brain's hearing centers might just process speech along with other sounds. But new work suggests that speech gets some special treatment very early on.
item.itunes:summary: Scientists thought that the brain's hearing centers might just process speech along with other sounds. But new work suggests that speech gets some special treatment very early on. Read more at QuantaMagazine.org. Music is "Thought Bot" by Audionautix.

item.title: Biologists Rethink the Logic Behind Cells’ Molecular Signals
item.description:
The molecular signaling systems of complex cells are nothing like simple electronic circuits. The logic governing their operation is riotously complex — but it has advantages.

The post Biologists Rethink the Logic Behind Cells’ Molecular Signals first appeared on Quanta Magazine
item.itunes:title: Biologists Rethink the Logic Behind Cells’ Molecular Signals
item.itunes:subtitle: The molecular signaling systems of complex cells are nothing like simple electronic circuits. The logic governing their operation is riotously complex - but it has advantages.
